awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Rapid Planar PCR for COVID-19 Testing
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to develop the first point-of-contact molecular diagnostic as a tool for COVID-19 testing. The investigator envisions a point-of-contact test being performed before someone passes through a door, checkpoint, airport gate, or border.  Many of the critical strategies for this work have already been established, including the feasibility of performing a one-step assay on various viruses, including SARS-CoV-2, the virus responsible for COVID-19. This project provides a basis for expanding the capability of the method/diagnostic tool, with the goal of establishing a reliable method for detecting COVID-19 positivity from saliva in less than 2 minutes at a cost of approximately $2/test.  When functional, this tool could be used routinely to test for hidden spreaders of disease at airports, entrances to hospitals or long-term care facilities. Similarly, the method could be used to screen employees when they arrive to work at health care facilities or other large facilities to protect essential workers and patients. Finally, the method could be used for routine screening at large facilities such as factories, food processing or distribution facilities, and large government buildings, allowing our economy to return to a more normal state. The research will also provide training for a postdoctoral fellow and an undergraduate

This project focuses on establishing a new method for PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction, a method used to rapidly make millions of copies of a DNA sample) that will realize the goal of a point-of-contact molecular diagnostic test for envelope viruses such as COVID-19.  Already established for this work are critical strategies: (1) for rapid, uniform cycling using optical heating; (2) for large scale partitioning to accelerate sample preparation without micro-patterning or microfluidics; and (3) for performing a one-step lysis/rp-PCR (rapid planar-PCR) assay on envelope viruses.  The Research Plan is organized under three objectives: (1) to extend the limited area heating due to use of individual LED/lens pairs to large areas through the design and fabrication of a printed circuit that will allow higher density of LEDs per zone, allow many more zones, simplify connections to the rest of the control circuitry, and allow use of surface mount LED drivers; (2) to show, once uniform, large area heating is established, that the diffusion limitation works to provide a very large level of partitioning, with a goal of achieving 1,000,000 partitioning sites in a 5 x 5 cm sample; and (3) to demonstrate the expected assay speed and detection limit (~2 minutes and ~100 copies/milliliter) by modifying reagents, temperatures, and time periods to achieve a good compromise between efficiency of the three steps (lysis, reverse transcription, PCR) overall assay speed, and limit-of detection. If successful, project results will provide the basis for rolling out a point-of-contact test that can be rapidly translated for clinical applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The COVID-19 pandemic has shown the need for better tools for testing for infectious disease. In particular, because of asymptomatic spreaders, it proved impossible to contain COVID-19 in an effective manner, leading to an enormous health, social, and economic impact. We are developing a new type of test that could help better contain or control infectious disease. In particular, we are developing what we think is the first point-of-contact test for viral diseases such as COVID-19. Point-of-care tests already exist, which require approximately 15-20 minutes to perform the test. By contrast, with a point-of-contact test, our goal is 2 minutes between acquiring a sample and receiving the test result. Besides high speed, we also seek a low cost for routine use, approximately $2/test. These are challenging goals, but ones we believe can be achieved. A point-of-contact test could be performed before someone passes through a door, checkpoint, airport gate, or border. It could be used to test for infected individuals at airports, border crossings, or entrances to hospitals, long-term care facilities, or large employment centers. Ideally, such routine “portal” testing could achieve a better balance between minimizing disease spread and minimizing societal and economic impact. Because the genetic sequence of a new disease can be determined very rapidly with next-generation sequencing methods and DNA primers can be rapidly prepared, this test could be rapidly adapted to emerging diseases.

Our test is based on PCR (polymerase chain reaction), a very common technique for disease testing and other applications. PCR is capable of producing millions of copies of a DNA sequence. This large amplification is the basis for sensitive PCR tests. For a virus such as SARS-CoV-2, which causes COVID-19, there is more to a test than PCR alone. The genetic sequence for SARS-CoV-2 is coded in RNA rather than DNA. In addition, the virus is surrounded by a membrane. Thus prior to PCR, two additional steps are required. First lysis, or rupturing the virus membrane, and second, reverse transcription, a process that converts the RNA sequence to a DNA form. PCR requires cyclic heating and cooling. We are developing an instrument that can do this cycling very rapidly based on optical heating. To this end, we have developed new printed circuit boards and optics for the heating light source, new cartridges for the samples, new illumination sources for the test readout, specialized cooling hardware, and software for system control and a graphical user interface. Managing temperature control has been a major focus throughout. We have made multiple iterations on the design, fabrication, and testing of most components of the system to improve performance. In addition, we have tested multiple backup solutions and multiple overall system geometries. At this point we have a strong design to use as a basis for additional development.

This project has supported the training of three undergraduate students and one junior staff member. The research performed in this project is expected to have a positive impact on society through development of better testing methods for infectious disease and pandemics. In addition, the rapid results and simple implementation could prove useful in a variety of other applications requiring PCR DNA analysis such as epidemiological, environmental, waste monitoring, agricultural, and forensic uses.
